subject: Critical Thinking
title: Begging the Question: Circular Reasoning
description: A quick, practical guide to Begging the Question: Circular Reasoning.

hook.text: 'The Bible is true because it's the word of God. How do we know? The Bible says so.' The conclusion is the premise.

buildup.text: Begging the question: the conclusion is hidden in the premises. It's circular reasoning â€” using your claim to prove itself.

discovery.text: Aristotle identified it as 'petitio principii.' It often hides in complex language so the circularity isn't obvious.

twist.text: Many common arguments beg the question: 'Free markets are best because economic freedom is the highest value.' That's.

climax.text: The fallacy often goes unnoticed because the premise and conclusion are phrased differently, disguising the repetition.

punchline.text: If your proof is your conclusion rephrased, you've proven nothing.

quiz.question: What is begging the question?
options: An argument where the conclusion is assumed in the premises
